ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Specific knowledge about the connection between gender and US empire + US history knowledge, critical thinking about pop-culture and how it perpetuates ideas about gender and US empire, Application of historical concepts to modern day issues and pop-culture.

In this class, I learned a lot about how gender and sexuality relate to U.S. foreign policy and about the different ways that gender intersects with race and class. It was interesting to see the impacts of how people think about gender and sexuality on U.S. history.
I learned how to evaluate, interpret, and create meaningful arguments about U.S history, imperialism, and its relationships to gender and sexuality.

I re-learned so much about U.S. history in this course and feel much more knowledgeable about the world and the role gender and sexuality play in politics and interactions after taking this course. I am now better equipped to think about gender and sexuality and make connections between primary and secondary sources. I also believe that this course improved my writing skills and my ability to come up with effective theses.

I learned a lot about writing essays in this course-- I wasn't expecting to feel challenged in thesis making but I actually learned a lot about demonstrative/ meaningful writing of my own theories rather than repackaging ideas from the text. i also learned a lot about history as a connected fabric rather than isolated events.
I developed many writing skills such as comparing historical events/movements to current events/movements, how to analyze primary sources, and how to examine themes in sources such as a movie.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - readings and discussions are VERY interesting. I looked forward every week to coming to this class and discussing the readings with the professor and other students. The essays, though difficult, were also enjoyable and thought-provoking. Overall, the atmosphere of the class was friendly and very collaborative. The class was kind of what you made of it - you could put a lot of effort into the class in terms of discussions, readings, and essays, and they you also got a lot out of it, but there were also ways to do less work and still succeed academically. 
Weaknesses - There were a lot of readings, and it was sometimes difficult to understand what was important to sink time into understanding versus what was less important and could be skimmed for the sake of time. It did often feel like the whole of the class held the same opinion on the subjects we were talking about, which made discussions feel a little one-sided, but that wasnt the professors fault and Im not sure what could be done about that - and I would want to sacrifice the way the discussions felt safe for everyone to participate.

This class was fun to take part in, and I loved the class environment that was created. As well, you are given a lot of intellectual freedom in this class, which I enjoyed. However, sometimes the instructions were a bit unclear, so that made some of the essays slightly difficult.

Strengths of the course were the content and the instructor. The content was by far some of the most interesting stuff Ive ever studied in school, and TZB made every lecture super engaging and interactive. I always felt like our insights were welcome and contributed meaningfully to the material.

The syllabus was fantastic; I found all of the readings very interesting and we were given a nice combination of assignments throughout the semester. I appreciated the opportunity to do a presentation related to the readings and I thought the essay prompts were amazing. I also liked the opportunity for class and small-group discussions. I think that the discussions could have benefitted at times from more structure to ensure that more voices could be heard equally.

I think the strengths are the amount of detail we are given with each assignment, so you feel prepared to write/read because you know what is expected of you. I also think TZB is a great lecturer and knows how to balance between instructive and interactive classroom styles which was really nice.

Strengths of this course is that it is well organized and very entertaining. All the materials and readings were very insightful. This class changed my perspective by teaching me how to view things with a historical and critical lens. A weakness is that the readings could be pretty long but this allowed for the developing of reading skills.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. I had a really good time in this class and learned a lot. Theres a lot of writing, so it is a great way to improve those skills while learning about an interesting topic. I came out of the class with a lot more knowledge about US history from the lens of American ideas of gender and sexuality, which has helped me better understand pop-culture better and has helped me see the roots of some issues that are impacting us today. If you are lucky enough to get into this class, please take it!

I would recommend this course if you want to learn more about the ways that gender and foreign policy intersect or if you want a supportive class environment. It is a fairly easy workload in comparison to other Yale courses, but it is great enough that I wouldn't take this class if you simply want a gut.
Yes, definitely. It was my favorite class of the semester.
Absolutely! It was so interesting and unlike anything I had ever taken. I think about the world differently after taking this course and would highly recommend it to others!
Yes, it's great for freshman to explore and improve their essay writing and was a fun class to take.
Yes I would, this course was very interesting and the workload was manageable. I enjoyed the smaller class of first years.
